    Prolog is Awesome!

    03 Jun 2010

    So one chapter of the 7 languages in 7 weeks book was Prolog. Yeah, it’s an older language but it’s really fun.Â  Since i’ve been doing imperative style programming for so long it was quite literally mind-bending.Â  It kept me up late playing like I used to with Java way back in the late 90s, in other words it was freakin’ fun.Â  At any rate, I won’t regurgitate any summaries of Prolog (there are plenty), but i will leave some code examples.

    The example listed below was a totally simple program designed to return the smallest integer from a list (totally basic I know), but what i’m also including here is the ‘unit test and command line version too just for the hell of it.

    #file d2_2.pl
    

    smallest([L,R],S) :- L<R -> S=L;S=R,!.
    smallest([H|T], S) :- smallest(T,ST), smallest([H,ST], S),!.
    smallest([S],S).
    

    #file test_d2_2.pl
    

    assert(Source,Expected,Expected) :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write('\nOKÂ Â  - For '), write(Source),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write(' expected '),write(Expected), write(' and'),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write(' received '),write(Expected), !.

    assert(Source,Expected,Received) :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write('\nFAIL - For '), write(Source),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write(' expected '),write(Expected), write(' but'),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write(' received '),write(Received), !.

    assert_smallest(List,Expected) :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  smallest(List,Received), assert(List,Expected,Received).

    test_smallest :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write('Begin Tests------------------------------------------------'),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  assert_smallest([3,1,2],1),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  assert_smallest([-66,32,123,1223,10003,1,2],-66),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  assert_smallest([0],0),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  assert_smallest([-1,0],-1),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write('\n-----------------------------------------------------------\n').

    :- include(d2_2).
    :- initialization(test_smallest).
    

    #file cmd_d2_2.pl
    

    iargs(R) :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  argument_list(S),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  iargs(S,R).

    iargs([],[]).
    iargs([H|T],R) :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  iargs(T,TR),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  number_atom(HASINT,H),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  append([HASINT],TR,R).



    q :-
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  iargs(S),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  smallest(S,SM),
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  write('Smallest of '),

    So, yeah, i know that’s totally simple but for people just starting out it might prove useful.Â
